question_details.query: What are the documented benefits and harms of adopting reduced tillage systems on European farms?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Multiple studies have found that reduced tillage systems in Europe can have a range of effects on soil, biodiversity, and crop yields. In terms of soil health, twelve studies showed higher soil organic carbon under reduced tillage (906), and eight studies found it maintained or increased soil organic matter and improved soil structure (906). Four studies also noted an increase in microbes and earthworm populations (906). However, the effects are not all positive. Three replicated trials reported higher soil compaction under reduced tillage (906). The impact on soil erosion is mixed; seven trials showed reduced soil loss, but two showed increased soil loss when there was no crop cover (906). For biodiversity, 34 studies from European countries found some positive effects on earthworms, invertebrates, weeds, or farmland birds (126). Some studies also found higher species richness or diversity for some or all bird groups (211). Reduced tillage fields can have higher densities of certain bird species, with one review noting that no-till systems provide more invertebrate bird food resources (126, 211). On the other hand, 26 studies found that reducing tillage had negative, null, or inconsistent effects on some invertebrates, earthworms, weeds, and bird species (126). The effects on crop yields are also inconsistent. One study found lower yields under minimum or no-tillage (906), another found no effect of tillage on yield (906), and a third found higher yields when subsoiling was performed (906).
summary_statements: Reduced tillage systems in Europe can have a range of effects on soil, biodiversity, and crop yields.
Reduced tillage has been shown to result in higher soil organic carbon.
Reduced tillage can maintain or increase soil organic matter.
Reduced tillage can improve soil structure.
Reduced tillage can lead to an increase in microbes and earthworm populations.
Higher soil compaction can be a result of reduced tillage.
The impact of reduced tillage on soil erosion is mixed.
Reduced tillage can lead to reduced soil loss.
Reduced tillage can lead to increased soil loss when there is no crop cover.
Reduced tillage in European countries has shown some positive effects on earthworms, invertebrates, weeds, or farmland birds.
Higher species richness or diversity for some or all bird groups has been found in reduced tillage systems.
Reduced tillage fields can have higher densities of certain bird species.
No-till systems can provide more invertebrate bird food resources.
Reducing tillage can have negative, null, or inconsistent effects on some invertebrates, earthworms, weeds, and bird species.
The effects of reduced tillage on crop yields are inconsistent.
Minimum or no-tillage can result in lower yields.
In some cases, there is no effect of tillage on crop yield.
Higher crop yields were found when subsoiling was performed in reduced tillage systems.

question_details.query: How do the effects of growing cover crops between crop rows compare to growing them when a field is empty?

summary_details.relevant_summary: One study found that in plots with cover crops (living mulches) grown between broccoli plants, fewer aphids were parasitized compared to plots without cover crops (1394). In contrast, two other studies found there were fewer aphids in plots with cover crops between broccoli plants compared to those without (1394). Where cover crops are grown in winter, some studies found they can lead to less severely diseased lettuces (1394), and less water was lost through drainage, runoff or evaporation (1357). However, growing cover crops in winter can also lead to lower cash crop yields (1351). Four studies found that less nitrate was leached from soils with winter cover crops compared to soils without them (1357).
summary_statements: In plots with cover crops grown between broccoli plants, one study found that fewer aphids were parasitized compared to plots without cover crops.
Two other studies found there were fewer aphids in plots with cover crops between broccoli plants compared to plots without cover crops.
Some studies found that growing cover crops in winter can lead to less severely diseased lettuces.
When cover crops are grown in winter, less water was lost through drainage, runoff or evaporation.
Growing cover crops in winter can lead to lower cash crop yields.
Four studies found that less nitrate was leached from soils with winter cover crops compared to soils without winter cover crops.

question_details.query: What are the comparative effects of using green manures versus cover crops on soil organic carbon and crop yield?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Two controlled, randomized, replicated studies in India and Pakistan on clay loam soil found that growing green manures led to higher soil organic carbon and increased grain yields (908).
For cover crops, one meta-analysis and ten replicated, controlled studies found more organic matter (mostly measured as carbon) in soils with winter cover crops compared to those without (1345). One replicated study and one review also found increased soil carbon levels under cover crops, with a further increase when legumes were included (898). Another study reported more carbon accumulation in soils with cover crops (1345). The effect of cover crops on crop yield is varied. Six studies found lower cash crop yields in plots with winter cover crops, while three studies found higher yields (1351). Eight studies showed inconsistent differences, and seven studies found no differences in cash crop yields between plots with or without cover crops (1351). However, eight studies found higher cash crop yields when legumes were used as winter cover crops compared to non-legumes (1351), and one study found higher tomato yield from soils that had a ryegrass cover crop (898).
summary_statements: Two controlled, randomized, replicated studies in India and Pakistan on clay loam soil found that growing green manures led to higher soil organic carbon.
Two controlled, randomized, replicated studies in India and Pakistan on clay loam soil found that growing green manures led to increased grain yields.
For cover crops, one meta-analysis and ten replicated, controlled studies found more organic matter in soils with winter cover crops compared to soils without winter cover crops.
One replicated study and one review found increased soil carbon levels under cover crops.
One replicated study and one review found a further increase in soil carbon when legumes were included with cover crops.
Another study reported more carbon accumulation in soils with cover crops.
The effect of cover crops on crop yield is varied.
Six studies found lower cash crop yields in plots with winter cover crops.
Three studies found higher cash crop yields in plots with winter cover crops.
Eight studies showed inconsistent differences in cash crop yields between plots with or without cover crops.
Seven studies found no differences in cash crop yields between plots with or without cover crops.
Eight studies found higher cash crop yields when legumes were used as winter cover crops compared to non-legumes.
One study found higher tomato yield from soils that had a ryegrass cover crop.

question_details.query: What are the benefits and drawbacks of different tillage practices on sandy loam soils in Europe?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Studies in Europe and other regions on sandy loam and other soil types have examined the effects of different tillage practices. 

Benefits of reduced tillage that were identified include an increase in microbes, earthworm species, and microbe activity [906]. Reduced tillage has also been found to decrease soil compaction in some studies, leading to reduced water runoff [906]. Furthermore, it has been shown to lower soil loss and runoff compared to conventional ploughing [906]. Twelve studies noted higher soil organic carbon under no-tillage or reduced tillage systems [906], and eight studies observed maintained or increased soil organic matter and improved soil structure [906].

Drawbacks and mixed results for reduced tillage were also reported. Three replicated trials found higher soil compaction under reduced tillage [906]. Two trials showed that no-tillage increased soil loss when there was no crop cover [906]. While some studies showed benefits, others found mixed effects on microbe diversity, no effect on earthworm or microbe activity, or mixed effects on soil nitrogen levels [906]. One trial in Spain even found greater soil organic carbon in conventionally tilled soil [906]. In terms of yield, one Canadian study found lower yields under minimum or no-tillage, while a Portuguese study found no effect from the tillage treatment [906].

Conventional ploughing and sub-soiling were found in three trials in Europe and India to increase the soil's ability to absorb water and its water content [906].

Related practices on sandy loam soils include the use of cover crops and mulch. Cover crops have been found to increase bacterial numbers and activity in Spain and reduce erosion in France [897]. Adding mulch has been shown in European studies to increase soil animal and fungal numbers, diversity, and activity [887], and to reduce soil erosion and runoff [887].
summary_statements: Studies in Europe and other regions on sandy loam and other soil types have examined the effects of different tillage practices.
Identified benefits of reduced tillage include an increase in microbes, earthworm species, and microbe activity.
Reduced tillage has been found to decrease soil compaction in some studies.
A decrease in soil compaction from reduced tillage can lead to reduced water runoff.
Reduced tillage has been shown to lower soil loss and runoff compared to conventional ploughing.
Twelve studies noted higher soil organic carbon under no-tillage or reduced tillage systems.
Eight studies observed that no-tillage or reduced tillage systems maintained or increased soil organic matter.
Eight studies observed that no-tillage or reduced tillage systems improved soil structure.
Drawbacks and mixed results for reduced tillage were also reported.
Three replicated trials found higher soil compaction under reduced tillage.
Two trials showed that no-tillage increased soil loss when there was no crop cover.
Some studies found that reduced tillage had mixed effects on microbe diversity.
Some studies found reduced tillage had no effect on earthworm or microbe activity.
Some studies found reduced tillage had mixed effects on soil nitrogen levels.
One trial in Spain found greater soil organic carbon in conventionally tilled soil.
One Canadian study found lower crop yields under minimum or no-tillage.
A Portuguese study found no effect on crop yield from the tillage treatment.
Conventional ploughing and sub-soiling were found in three trials to increase the soil's ability to absorb water.
Conventional ploughing and sub-soiling were found in three trials to increase the soil's water content.
Related practices on sandy loam soils include the use of cover crops and mulch.
Cover crops have been found to increase bacterial numbers and activity.
Cover crops have been found to reduce erosion.
Adding mulch has been shown in European studies to increase soil animal and fungal numbers, diversity, and activity.
Adding mulch has been shown to reduce soil erosion and runoff.

question_details.query: What evidence exists from studies in the USA regarding the impact of cover crops and crop residue management on crop yields?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Regarding the impact of cover crops on crop yields in the USA, the evidence shows varied results. Six replicated, controlled studies in Spain and the USA found lower cash crop yields in some instances with winter cover crops, whereas three similar studies in Italy and the USA found higher yields [1351]. Eight studies in Italy and the USA reported inconsistent differences in cash crop yields between plots with and without cover crops, and seven controlled studies in France, Israel, Spain, and the USA found no differences [1351]. One US study also found inconsistent yield differences with summer cover crops [1351]. The type of cover crop used appears to be a significant factor, as eight studies in Italy and the USA found higher cash crop yields when legumes were used as winter cover crops compared to non-legumes, and one US study found higher yields with a mixture of legumes and grasses compared to legumes alone [1351]. 

In terms of crop residue management, a replicated study in the USA found that tillage can have mixed effects on soil erosion when crop residues are removed [907]. However, the studies that found higher crop yields when retaining residues were conducted in Australia and China, not the USA [907].
summary_statements: Evidence regarding the impact of cover crops on crop yields in the USA shows varied results.
Some replicated, controlled studies in Spain and the USA found lower cash crop yields in certain instances with winter cover crops.
Some replicated, controlled studies in Italy and the USA found higher cash crop yields with winter cover crops.
Some studies in Italy and the USA reported inconsistent differences in cash crop yields between plots with and without cover crops.
Some controlled studies in France, Israel, Spain, and the USA found no differences in cash crop yields between plots with and without cover crops.
A US study found inconsistent yield differences with summer cover crops.
The type of cover crop used appears to be a significant factor.
Some studies in Italy and the USA found higher cash crop yields when legumes were used as winter cover crops compared to non-legumes.
A US study found higher yields with a mixture of legumes and grasses compared to legumes alone.
A replicated study in the USA found that tillage can have mixed effects on soil erosion when crop residues are removed.
The studies that found higher crop yields when retaining residues were conducted in Australia and China, not the USA.

question_details.query: What is the available evidence on how incorporating grass or pasture into arable systems affects soil nutrients?

summary_details.relevant_summary: One replicated study from Denmark on sandy-loam soil showed that reducing the extent of grass pasture in leys reduced the undesirable uptake of nitrogen by grasses, therefore requiring lower rates of fertilizer for subsequent crops [900].
summary_statements: A replicated study from Denmark on sandy-loam soil showed that reducing the extent of grass pasture in leys reduced the undesirable uptake of nitrogen by grasses.
Reducing the extent of grass pasture in leys required lower rates of fertilizer for subsequent crops, according to a replicated study from Denmark on sandy-loam soil.

question_details.query: What actions can be taken on European farms with sandy-loam soils to improve soil structure?

summary_details.relevant_summary: One study in India found that incorporating straw into the soil improved soil structure, but a UK-based trial found that incorporating straw via discing did not improve compacted, anaerobic soils [910]. Adding mulch to crops has been shown to improve soil structure, as well as increase the number and diversity of soil animals and fungi [887]. Converting to organic farming has been linked to higher numbers and diversity of soil organisms and increased soil carbon levels [895].
summary_statements: One study in India found that incorporating straw into the soil improved soil structure.
A UK-based trial found that incorporating straw via discing did not improve compacted, anaerobic soils.
Adding mulch to crops has been shown to improve soil structure.
Adding mulch to crops has been shown to increase the number and diversity of soil animals and fungi.
Converting to organic farming has been linked to higher numbers and diversity of soil organisms.
Converting to organic farming has been linked to increased soil carbon levels.

question_details.query: Which are the most consistently beneficial actions for increasing microbial biomass in soil?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Eleven replicated, randomized, controlled studies from Italy, Spain, and the USA found more microbial biomass in soils with reduced tillage compared to conventional tillage [2307]. However, two studies from Spain and Syria found less microbial biomass, and two studies from Spain found similar amounts [2307]. One controlled, randomized, replicated trial in Italy on silty-clay soil discovered that applying a high rate of compost boosted soil organic matter, microbial biomass, and fruit output [889]. Regarding crop rotations, one replicated, controlled study in Italy reported more microbial biomass, while a study in Spain found less microbial biomass in soils with crop rotations compared to continuous crops [2305].
summary_statements: Eleven replicated, randomized, controlled studies from Italy, Spain, and the USA found more microbial biomass in soils with reduced tillage compared to conventional tillage.
Two studies from Spain and Syria found less microbial biomass in soils with reduced tillage compared to conventional tillage.
Two studies from Spain found similar amounts of microbial biomass in soils with reduced tillage compared to conventional tillage.
One controlled, randomized, replicated trial in Italy on silty-clay soil discovered that applying a high rate of compost boosted soil organic matter.
One controlled, randomized, replicated trial in Italy on silty-clay soil discovered that applying a high rate of compost boosted microbial biomass.
One controlled, randomized, replicated trial in Italy on silty-clay soil discovered that applying a high rate of compost boosted fruit output.
One replicated, controlled study in Italy reported more microbial biomass in soils with crop rotations compared to continuous crops.
A study in Spain found less microbial biomass in soils with crop rotations compared to continuous crops.

question_details.query: What are the effects of incorporating leys or grasslands into arable farming systems in Europe?

summary_details.relevant_summary: A study in Denmark on sandy-loam soil showed that reducing the extent of grass pasture in leys lowered the uptake of nitrogen by grasses, which in turn reduced the fertilizer requirements for subsequent crops (900). In Finland, a controlled study revealed that creating clover leys led to a higher abundance of spiders and a lower number of pest insects when compared to a barley control plot (643). Furthermore, a UK study found that three-and-a-half-year leys had significantly greater earthworm species richness and abundance compared to one-year leys (643). However, another UK study noted that grass leys contained fewer plant species than nine other conservation measures (643). Evidence regarding the impact of organic farming on wild bees is varied; three replicated trials in Europe or Canada indicated a higher abundance of wild bees under organic arable farming compared to conventional methods, with one of these studies also showing greater bee diversity in organically farmed wheat fields and adjacent mown fallow strips (25). Conversely, three other replicated trials in Europe or the USA found no significant difference in the numbers of bumblebees, bumblebee species, or wild bees visiting flowering crops between conventional and organic arable farms (25).
summary_statements: A study in Denmark on sandy-loam soil showed that reducing the extent of grass pasture in leys lowered the uptake of nitrogen by grasses.
Lowering the uptake of nitrogen by grasses in leys reduced the fertilizer requirements for subsequent crops.
A controlled study in Finland revealed that creating clover leys led to a higher abundance of spiders when compared to a barley control plot.
A controlled study in Finland revealed that creating clover leys led to a lower number of pest insects when compared to a barley control plot.
A UK study found that three-and-a-half-year leys had significantly greater earthworm species richness compared to one-year leys.
A UK study found that three-and-a-half-year leys had significantly greater earthworm abundance compared to one-year leys.
A UK study noted that grass leys contained fewer plant species than nine other conservation measures.
Evidence regarding the impact of organic farming on wild bees is varied.
Three replicated trials in Europe or Canada indicated a higher abundance of wild bees under organic arable farming compared to conventional methods.
One study showed greater bee diversity in organically farmed wheat fields and adjacent mown fallow strips.
Three replicated trials in Europe or the USA found no significant difference in the numbers of bumblebees visiting flowering crops between conventional and organic arable farms.
Three replicated trials in Europe or the USA found no significant difference in the number of bumblebee species visiting flowering crops between conventional and organic arable farms.
Three replicated trials in Europe or the USA found no significant difference in the numbers of wild bees visiting flowering crops between conventional and organic arable farms.

question_details.query: How do the effects of amending soil with fresh plant material compare to retaining crop residues in the field?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Amending the soil with fresh plant material or crop remains has led to increased microbial biomass [910], improved soil structure [910], and reduced soil loss [910]. It has also been found to result in higher levels of soil nitrogen and organic carbon [910]. However, the effects on nutrient loss can be varied [910]. In terms of yield, amending the soil can lead to higher yields for certain crops [910].

Retaining crop residues has been associated with a higher microbial biomass [907], decreased water runoff, increased water storage, and reduced soil erosion [907]. This practice has also been shown to increase soil organic carbon and nitrogen levels, leading to higher yields [907].

Incorporating plant remains that produce weed-controlling chemicals can reduce weed growth, but the effects may be temporary and can vary [728]. This practice has shown mixed results on crop growth and yield [728].

When using a mix of organic and inorganic amendments, studies have found higher microbial biomass and activity, as well as more organic carbon in the soil [902]. This mixture was also more effective at reducing cracks in dry soil compared to inorganic fertilizers alone [902] and was found to increase maize yield [902].
summary_statements: Amending the soil with fresh plant material or crop remains has led to increased microbial biomass.
Amending the soil with fresh plant material or crop remains has led to improved soil structure.
Amending the soil with fresh plant material or crop remains has led to reduced soil loss.
Amending the soil with fresh plant material or crop remains has been found to result in higher levels of soil nitrogen and organic carbon.
The effects of amending the soil with fresh plant material or crop remains on nutrient loss can be varied.
Amending the soil with fresh plant material or crop remains can lead to higher yields for certain crops.
Retaining crop residues has been associated with a higher microbial biomass.
Retaining crop residues has been associated with decreased water runoff, increased water storage, and reduced soil erosion.
Retaining crop residues has been shown to increase soil organic carbon and nitrogen levels.
Retaining crop residues has been shown to lead to higher yields.
Incorporating plant remains that produce weed-controlling chemicals can reduce weed growth.
The weed-controlling effects of incorporating certain plant remains may be temporary and can vary.
Incorporating plant remains that produce weed-controlling chemicals has shown mixed results on crop growth and yield.
Using a mix of organic and inorganic amendments can result in higher microbial biomass and activity.
Using a mix of organic and inorganic amendments can result in more organic carbon in the soil.
A mixture of organic and inorganic amendments was more effective at reducing cracks in dry soil compared to inorganic fertilizers alone.
A mixture of organic and inorganic amendments was found to increase maize yield.

question_details.query: What evidence is available from studies in the UK on how soil amendments affect nutrient loss?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Three of five replicated trials from the UK and New Zealand that measured the effect of applying nitrification inhibitors to the soil found reduced nitrate losses and nitrous oxide emissions (909). One of these trials found the method of application influenced the effect and one trial found no effect on nitrate loss (909). One trial found reduced nutrient and soil loss when aluminium sulphate was applied to the soil (909). Three randomized, replicated studies from Canada, Spain, the UK and the USA found reduced nutrient loss and higher nitrogen levels when farmyard or poultry manure was applied (911). One of the studies also found lower nutrient loss when farmyard manure was applied in the winter rather than autumn (911). However, one controlled, replicated study found higher nitrate leaching (911).
summary_statements: Three of five replicated trials from the UK and New Zealand that measured the effect of applying nitrification inhibitors to the soil found reduced nitrate losses.
Three of five replicated trials from the UK and New Zealand that measured the effect of applying nitrification inhibitors to the soil found reduced nitrous oxide emissions.
One trial on the application of nitrification inhibitors found the method of application influenced the effect on nutrient loss.
One trial on the application of nitrification inhibitors found no effect on nitrate loss.
One trial found reduced nutrient loss when aluminium sulphate was applied to the soil.
One trial found reduced soil loss when aluminium sulphate was applied to the soil.
Three randomized, replicated studies from Canada, Spain, the UK and the USA found reduced nutrient loss when farmyard or poultry manure was applied.
Three randomized, replicated studies from Canada, Spain, the UK and the USA found higher nitrogen levels when farmyard or poultry manure was applied.
One study found lower nutrient loss when farmyard manure was applied in the winter rather than in the autumn.
One controlled, replicated study on the application of manure found higher nitrate leaching.

question_details.query: How do the effects of cover crops on soil organic matter differ between studies in Europe and the USA?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Ten studies from the USA, France, and Spain showed an increase in soil organic matter with ground cover (1367). In contrast, two European studies that focused on growing cover crops in empty fields revealed no significant impact on soil organic matter levels (898). Additionally, a German trial found no effect on soil organic matter from growing cover crops beneath the main crop (897). However, other studies in Europe and the USA have shown positive effects. For instance, a study in Denmark indicated that cover crops increased soil carbon levels (898), and three US studies reported similar findings (898).
summary_statements: Ten studies from the USA, France, and Spain showed an increase in soil organic matter with ground cover.
Two European studies that focused on growing cover crops in empty fields revealed no significant impact on soil organic matter levels.
A German trial found no effect on soil organic matter from growing cover crops beneath the main crop.
Other studies in Europe and the USA have shown positive effects of cover crops on soil organic matter.
A study in Denmark indicated that cover crops increased soil carbon levels.
Three US studies reported that cover crops increased soil carbon levels.

question_details.query: How do the effects of retaining crop residues on-site compare with incorporating plant material brought from elsewhere?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
One replicated study in Mexico indicated that retaining crop residues increased microbial biomass [907]. A review noted that this practice reduced water runoff and soil erosion, while also increasing water storage [907]. However, a replicated site comparison in Canada found mixed effects on soil physical properties [907]. Two randomized, replicated trials in Australia and China observed higher soil organic carbon and nitrogen when residues were retained, with one trial showing this effect only when fertilizer was also applied [907]. These trials also reported higher yields, though one trial specified this outcome was only achieved in combination with fertilizer application and no-tillage [907].

Amending soil with fresh plant material or crop remains was found to increase microbial biomass in one randomized, replicated experiment in Belgium [910]. A study from India showed improved soil structure from incorporating straw [910]. However, a before-and-after trial in the UK found that incorporating straw did not improve compacted, anaerobic soils [910]. On the topic of erosion, one randomized, replicated study from Canada and India found that straw addition reduced soil loss, while another reported mixed effects depending on the soil type [910]. In terms of nutrient loss, four replicated studies from the UK, USA, and Belgium reported higher soil nitrogen levels when compost or straw was applied, but the results were mixed when processed wastes were added [910]. Six studies in China, Denmark, and India all found higher carbon levels when plant material was added to the soil [910].

Incorporating plant remains that produce weed-controlling chemicals has shown varied results. Out of six studies, three found a reduction in weed growth [728]. Two of three studies found that crop growth was inhibited by such plant remains, but this could be minimized by changing the application timing [728]. Yield effects were also inconsistent, with studies finding positive, negative, and mixed results [728].
summary_statements: A replicated study in Mexico indicated that retaining crop residues increased microbial biomass.
A review noted that retaining crop residues reduced water runoff and soil erosion.
A review noted that retaining crop residues increased water storage.
A replicated site comparison in Canada found that retaining crop residues had mixed effects on soil physical properties.
Two randomized, replicated trials in Australia and China observed higher soil organic carbon and nitrogen when crop residues were retained.
One trial showed higher soil organic carbon and nitrogen from retaining crop residues only when fertilizer was also applied.
Two trials reported higher yields when crop residues were retained.
One trial specified that higher yields were only achieved when retaining crop residues was combined with fertilizer application and no-tillage.
A randomized, replicated experiment in Belgium found that amending soil with fresh plant material or crop remains increased microbial biomass.
A study from India showed that incorporating straw improved soil structure.
A before-and-after trial in the UK found that incorporating straw did not improve compacted, anaerobic soils.
One randomized, replicated study from Canada and India found that straw addition reduced soil loss.
Another study on straw addition reported mixed effects on soil loss, depending on the soil type.
Four replicated studies from the UK, USA, and Belgium reported higher soil nitrogen levels when compost or straw was applied.
The results for soil nitrogen levels were mixed when processed wastes were added to the soil.
Six studies in China, Denmark, and India all found higher carbon levels when plant material was added to the soil.
Incorporating plant remains that produce weed-controlling chemicals has shown varied results.
Three out of six studies found that incorporating plant remains that produce weed-controlling chemicals caused a reduction in weed growth.
Two of three studies found that crop growth was inhibited by plant remains that produce weed-controlling chemicals.
The inhibition of crop growth by plant remains could be minimized by changing the application timing.
The effects of incorporating plant remains on crop yield were inconsistent, with studies finding positive, negative, and mixed results.

question_details.query: What are the documented benefits and drawbacks of using crop rotation on farms in Canada?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Crop rotation in potato farming systems has been documented to reduce pest populations and crop diseases (719). Some studies also found that crop rotation increased crop yield and profit, while reducing the need for insecticides (719). The inclusion of legumes in crop rotations was found to increase the number of microbes and the diversity of soil animals, and the inclusion of forage crops in rotations reduced rainwater runoff and soil loss (857). Furthermore, some studies found that crop rotation, especially with legumes, increased soil organic carbon and matter (857).

However, there are also documented drawbacks. One study found that pest populations increased with crop rotation, and another noted that longer crop rotations could lead to lower levels of soil organic matter (719, 857). Depending on the crops used, studies have found both increases and decreases in pest populations and yield (719). Other studies have recorded decreased organic matter, nitrogen, and phosphorus in soils with crop rotations (1368). In some cases, crop rotations have been associated with decreased microbial biomass and higher carbon dioxide emissions (1368).
summary_statements: Crop rotation in potato farming systems has been documented to reduce pest populations.
Crop rotation in potato farming systems has been documented to reduce crop diseases.
Some studies found that crop rotation increased crop yield.
Some studies found that crop rotation increased profit.
Some studies found that crop rotation reduced the need for insecticides.
The inclusion of legumes in crop rotations was found to increase the number of microbes.
The inclusion of legumes in crop rotations was found to increase the diversity of soil animals.
The inclusion of forage crops in rotations reduced rainwater runoff.
The inclusion of forage crops in rotations reduced soil loss.
Some studies found that crop rotation, especially with legumes, increased soil organic carbon.
Some studies found that crop rotation, especially with legumes, increased soil organic matter.
One study found that pest populations increased with crop rotation.
One study noted that longer crop rotations could lead to lower levels of soil organic matter.
Depending on the crops used, studies have found increases in pest populations and yield.
Depending on the crops used, studies have found decreases in pest populations and yield.
Other studies have recorded decreased organic matter in soils with crop rotations.
Other studies have recorded decreased nitrogen in soils with crop rotations.
Other studies have recorded decreased phosphorus in soils with crop rotations.
In some cases, crop rotations have been associated with decreased microbial biomass.
In some cases, crop rotations have been associated with higher carbon dioxide emissions.

question_details.query: Which soil management practices are most consistently beneficial for increasing soil organic carbon?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Twelve studies from various countries found that no-tillage or reduced tillage systems resulted in higher soil organic carbon compared to conventional tillage (906). One review also indicated that combining no-tillage with cover cropping and manure application increases soil organic carbon (906). Four studies in Australia, Canada, and Denmark discovered that crop rotation, especially with the inclusion of legumes, increased soil organic carbon (857). Additionally, two randomized, replicated trials in Australia and China observed higher soil organic carbon and nitrogen when crop residues were retained (907).
summary_statements: No-tillage or reduced tillage systems result in higher soil organic carbon compared to conventional tillage.
Combining no-tillage with cover cropping and manure application increases soil organic carbon.
Crop rotation increases soil organic carbon.
The inclusion of legumes in crop rotation increases soil organic carbon.
Retaining crop residues results in higher soil organic carbon.
Retaining crop residues results in higher soil nitrogen.

question_details.query: What conservation actions have evidence from Canada for improving soil health, particularly biodiversity and organic matter?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Four randomized, replicated trials in Canada, Portugal, and Zambia found that including legumes in crop rotations increased the number of microbes and the diversity of soil animals [857]. Additionally, four studies in Australia, Canada, and Denmark showed that crop rotation, especially with legumes, increased soil organic carbon [857]. Three of five replicated trials in Canada, Portugal, and Syria also found increased soil organic matter when legumes were included in the rotation [857]. One randomized, replicated trial in Canada demonstrated that including forage crops in rotations reduced rainwater runoff and soil loss [857]. In contrast, one replicated trial in Canada on converting to organic farming found that soil nutrients were lower in organically managed soils [895], and another study in Canada on reducing fertilizer use found lower nutrient levels in low-input systems [904].
summary_statements: Including legumes in crop rotations increased the number of microbes.
Including legumes in crop rotations increased the diversity of soil animals.
Crop rotation, especially with legumes, increased soil organic carbon.
Including legumes in the rotation increased soil organic matter.
Including forage crops in rotations reduced rainwater runoff.
Including forage crops in rotations reduced soil loss.
Soil nutrients were lower in organically managed soils.
Reducing fertilizer use was found to result in lower nutrient levels in low-input systems.

question_details.query: How do the effects of amending soil with municipal wastes compare to using organic processing wastes?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Two controlled, replicated trials in Spain and the United Kingdom measured the effect of adding wastes to the soil (890, 891). One trial found that adding municipal compost to semi-arid soils greatly reduced soil loss and water runoff, while another found mixed results of adding composts and wastes (890). One trial found applying high rates of cotton gin compost and poultry manure improved soil structure and reduced soil loss, but increased nutrient loss (891). Another trial found improved nutrient retention and increased barley Hordeum vulgare yield when molasses were added (891). The soil types covered were coarse loamy and sandy loam for municipal wastes (890), and sandy-clay, sandy loam, and silty-clay for organic processing wastes (891).
summary_statements: Two controlled, replicated trials in Spain and the United Kingdom measured the effect of adding wastes to the soil.
One trial found that adding municipal compost to semi-arid soils greatly reduced soil loss and water runoff.
Another trial found mixed results of adding composts and wastes.
One trial found applying high rates of cotton gin compost and poultry manure improved soil structure.
One trial found applying high rates of cotton gin compost and poultry manure reduced soil loss.
One trial found applying high rates of cotton gin compost and poultry manure increased nutrient loss.
Another trial found improved nutrient retention when molasses were added.
Another trial found increased barley Hordeum vulgare yield when molasses were added.
The soil types covered for municipal wastes were coarse loamy and sandy loam.
The soil types covered for organic processing wastes were sandy-clay, sandy loam, and silty-clay.

question_details.query: What is the evidence for actions that reduce nutrient loss from sandy-loam soils?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Two replicated site comparison studies, one of which was also randomized, from Denmark and Norway discovered that delaying ploughing until spring resulted in decreased soil loss and nitrate leaching [712]. Three of five replicated trials in New Zealand and the UK that tested the effects of adding nitrification inhibitors to the soil revealed a decrease in nitrate losses and nitrous oxide emissions [909]. Another study revealed that applying aluminum sulfate to the soil reduced soil and nutrient loss [909]. According to a Canadian study, low-input farming systems had lower nutrient levels and yields [904].
summary_statements: Delaying ploughing until spring resulted in decreased soil loss and nitrate leaching.
Adding nitrification inhibitors to the soil revealed a decrease in nitrate losses.
Adding nitrification inhibitors to the soil revealed a decrease in nitrous oxide emissions.
Applying aluminum sulfate to the soil reduced soil and nutrient loss.
Low-input farming systems had lower nutrient levels and yields.

question_details.query: What are the effects of incorporating hedgerows or tree lines into agricultural land?

summary_details.relevant_summary: One replicated site comparison study in the UK and Switzerland found that retaining and enhancing hedgerows and other field boundary features was associated with higher brown hare density in arable sites but not in grassland sites, while another study found no increase in Irish hare numbers (2383). A replicated site comparison study in the UK found that establishing hedgerows alongside arable land increased the abundance of small mammals (2383). A controlled, randomized, replicated study in Canada found that intercropping with trees resulted in a higher diversity of arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi on sandy-loam soil (903). Three replicated site comparison studies in Australia found no difference in the number of bat species in agricultural areas with and without plantations of native trees (958). Two of the three studies also found no difference in bat activity, while the third found higher bat activity in plantations next to remnant native vegetation than in isolated plantations or over grazing land (958).
summary_statements: Retaining and enhancing hedgerows and other field boundary features was associated with higher brown hare density in arable sites.
Retaining and enhancing hedgerows was not associated with higher brown hare density in grassland sites.
A study found no increase in Irish hare numbers associated with hedgerows.
Establishing hedgerows alongside arable land increased the abundance of small mammals.
Intercropping with trees resulted in a higher diversity of arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi on sandy-loam soil.
Studies found no difference in the number of bat species in agricultural areas with and without plantations of native trees.
Some studies found no difference in bat activity between agricultural areas with and without plantations of native trees.
One study found higher bat activity in plantations next to remnant native vegetation than in isolated plantations or over grazing land.

question_details.query: What are the effects of reducing physical disturbance from machinery on agricultural soils?

summary_details.relevant_summary: No evidence was found for the effects of using brash mats during harvesting to avoid soil compaction in forests [1180].
summary_statements: No evidence was found for the effects of using brash mats during harvesting to avoid soil compaction in forests.

question_details.query: On sandy loam soils, how do the effects of amending with municipal waste compost compare to amending with organic processing waste composts?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Two controlled, replicated trials in Spain and the UK looked at the effects of adding municipal wastes to the soil (890). One of these trials discovered that applying municipal compost to semi-arid soils significantly decreased soil loss and water runoff, while the other trial had mixed results when adding composts and wastes (890). Two controlled, replicated studies in Spain and the United Kingdom examined the impact of incorporating composts into the soil (891). According to one experiment, using high rates of cotton gin compost and poultry manure enhanced soil structure and decreased soil loss, but it also raised nutrient loss (891). When molasses were introduced, another trial revealed enhanced nutrient retention and higher barley crop yields (891).
summary_statements: Two controlled, replicated trials in Spain and the UK looked at the effects of adding municipal wastes to the soil.
One trial discovered that applying municipal compost to semi-arid soils significantly decreased soil loss and water runoff.
Another trial had mixed results when adding composts and wastes.
Two controlled, replicated studies in Spain and the United Kingdom examined the impact of incorporating composts into the soil.
One experiment showed that using high rates of cotton gin compost and poultry manure enhanced soil structure and decreased soil loss.
The use of high rates of cotton gin compost and poultry manure also raised nutrient loss.
Another trial revealed that when molasses were introduced, nutrient retention was enhanced.
The introduction of molasses resulted in higher barley crop yields in a trial.

question_details.query: What does the evidence from the USA indicate about the effect of different agricultural practices on crop yields?

summary_details.relevant_summary: In the USA, the use of different agricultural practices has shown varied effects on crop yields. For instance, some studies found that growing winter cover crops in arable fields led to lower cash crop yields, while others reported higher or inconsistent yields (1351). One study even found inconsistent differences in cash crop yields with summer cover crops (1351). In terms of crop quality, some studies in the USA found differences in tomato quality with winter cover crops, while another found inconsistent differences in cash crop quality (1351). The use of legumes as winter cover crops was found to result in higher cash crop yields compared to non-legumes (1351). In orchards and vineyards, seeding grass between vine rows was found in some US studies to lower grape yields, while other studies found similar yields (1352). One study in the USA found that forgoing tillage between vine rows could result in higher grape yields and heavier clusters in some cases (1352). Regarding soil amendments, adding compost to the soil in the USA has led to higher, inconsistent, or similar crop yields in different studies (1346). One US study also found that adding fertilizer to compost did not lead to a difference in crop yields (1346).
summary_statements: In the USA, the use of different agricultural practices has shown varied effects on crop yields.
Some studies found that growing winter cover crops in arable fields led to lower cash crop yields.
Other studies reported that growing winter cover crops in arable fields led to higher or inconsistent cash crop yields.
One study found inconsistent differences in cash crop yields with summer cover crops.
Some studies in the USA found differences in tomato quality with winter cover crops.
Another study in the USA found inconsistent differences in cash crop quality with winter cover crops.
The use of legumes as winter cover crops was found to result in higher cash crop yields compared to non-legumes.
In US orchards and vineyards, some studies found that seeding grass between vine rows lowered grape yields.
Other studies in US orchards and vineyards found similar grape yields when seeding grass between vine rows.
One study in the USA found that forgoing tillage between vine rows could result in higher grape yields and heavier clusters in some cases.
Adding compost to the soil in the USA has led to higher, inconsistent, or similar crop yields in different studies.
One US study found that adding fertilizer to compost did not lead to a difference in crop yields.

question_details.query: Besides using crop rotation, what other actions can increase the biodiversity of soil organisms?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Reducing fertilizer, pesticide, or herbicide use can increase the diversity of soil invertebrates and microorganisms [904]. Controlling farm traffic might also have an impact on soil biodiversity. One study in Poland indicated that controlled traffic resulted in higher numbers and bacterial activity [899]. However, another study in Denmark found that microbial biomass was higher when farm traffic was not controlled [899]. Additionally, converting to organic farming has been shown to increase the number, diversity, and activity of soil organisms [895].
summary_statements: Reducing fertilizer, pesticide, or herbicide use can increase the diversity of soil invertebrates and microorganisms.
Controlling farm traffic might have an impact on soil biodiversity.
A study in Poland indicated that controlled traffic resulted in higher numbers and bacterial activity.
A study in Denmark found that microbial biomass was higher when farm traffic was not controlled.
Converting to organic farming has been shown to increase the number of soil organisms.
Converting to organic farming has been shown to increase the diversity of soil organisms.
Converting to organic farming has been shown to increase the activity of soil organisms.
